Engineering Example

Radioactive decay
Introduction
A cube of an impure radioactive ore is of side 10 cm. The number of radioactive decays taking place per cubic metre per second is given by \(R = 10^{23}(0.1-z)e^{-t/1000}\). The dependence on time represents a half-life of \(693\) seconds while the dependence on the vertical coordinate \(z\) represents some gravitational stratification. The value \(z=0\) represents the bottom of the cube and \(z=0.1\) represents the top of the cube. (Note that the dimensions are in metres so 10 cm becomes 0.1 m.)

What is the total number of decays taking place over the cube in the 100 seconds between \(t=0\) and \(t=100\)?

Solution

The total number of decays is given by the quadruple integral \[\displaystyle N = \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{t=0}^{100} 10^{23}(0.1-z)e^{-t/1000} \mathrm{d} t \,\mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x\] which may be evaluated as follows \begin{align*} N &= \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{t=0}^{100} 10^{23}(0.1-z)e^{-t/1000} \mathrm{d} t \,\mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{0.1} \bigg[ - 1000 \times 10^{23}(0.1-z)e^{-t/1000} \bigg]_{t=0}^{100} \;\mathrm{d}z\,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{0.1} \left[ 10^{26}(0.1-z)(1-e^{-0.1}) \right] \;\mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{0.1} \left[ 9.5 \times 10^{24}(0.1-z) \right] \;\mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= 9.5 \times 10^{24}\displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \bigg[ (0.1z-0.5z^2) \bigg]_{z=0}^{0.1} \;\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= 9.5 \times 10^{24}\displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \left[ 0.005 \right] \;\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= 0.005 \times 9.5 \times 10^{24}\displaystyle\int_{x=0}^{0.1} \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^{0.1} \;\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x \\ &= 0.005 \times 9.5 \times 10^{24} \times 0.1 \times 0.1 = 4.75 \times 10^{20} \end{align*} Thus the number of decays is approximately equal to \(4.75 \times 10^{20}\)
